content.text: Finders in webtau is the initial web element selection that could select one or more elements.
to select an element by a given

content.snippet:
def welcomeMessage = $('#welcome')
welcomeMessage.should == 'hello'

content.text: If more than one element is matched, the first one will be used for actions and assertions.

content.snippet:
def menu = $('ul li a')
menu.should == 'book'

content.text: will always work on a first element only, the matchers can work with a list of things.

content.snippet:
def menu = $('ul li a')
menu.should == ['book', 'orders', 'help']

content.text: Note: declaring element this way will not trigger element search right away.
You can use filters to narrow down elements selected by finders like
Filter comes in a way of
method. Parameter is one of the following

content.snippet:
def ordersMenu = $('ul li a').get(2)
ordersMenu.should == 'orders'
content.title: Number

content.snippet:
def ordersMenu = $('ul li a').get('orders')
ordersMenu.should == 'orders'
content.title: Text

content.snippet:
def ordersMenu = $('ul li a').get(~/ord/)
ordersMenu.should == 'orders'
content.title: Regexp

content.text: After you filtered, you can use finders again to find nested elements.

content.snippet:
def ordersMenu = $('ul li').get(2).find('a')
ordersMenu.should == 'orders'
content.title: Nested css selector

of various lengths, which you can optionally use for aesthetics.
underscore is optional and is there for aesthetics only

table("Col A", "Col B", "Col C").values(
        "v1a",   "v1b", "v1c",
        "v2a",   "v2b", "v2c")

 "Mike" | cell.above                | 14

content.snippet:
table("Name", "Start Date"             , "Games To Play",
     ________________________________________________________________,
      "John", LocalDate.of(2016, 6, 20), 10,
      "Bob" , cell.above               , cell.above.plus(1),
      "Mike", cell.above               , cell.above.plus(1))

TableDataCellValueGenerator<?> increment = cell.above.plus(1)

table("Name", "Start Date"             , "Games To Play",
     ________________________________________________________________,
      "John", LocalDate.of(2016, 6, 20), 10,
      "Bob" , cell.above               , increment,
      "Mike", cell.above               , increment)

browser.open("/search") // page is not be ing refreshed

to force open the page even if the page url already matches the passed one.

browser.reopen("/search") // page is going to be refreshed

search.submit('name')

browser.reopen("/search") // page is going to be refreshed
search.searchMessage.should == ''

content.text: to restart a browser and open last opened url.

content.snippet:
browser.open('/local-storage')
browser.localStorage.setItem('favoriteColor', 'pretty')

browser.refresh()
$('#favorite-color').should == 'pretty'

browser.restart()
$('#favorite-color').should == ''

content.text: Note: restarting creates a clean instance of a browser. Local storage is going to be reset.

content.text: Values that you access inside validation block are special values of
type. When you assert them using
they act as proxies that record every assertion that you do.
you can return values back from a validation block.

content.entry: can return simple value from get

content.text: When you return a value from a validation block, it automatically gets converted to its correspondent primitive.
Note: asserting that value after returning will not track and associated assertions with the call anymore. Use it only
to get values required for consequent test calls.
If you have a list of objects like
above, you can access all its children property value with

via a path instead of chaining

It is also possible to query arrays, including the ability to query for the Nth element from the end:

like logic checks on them. Accessing the values will mark them as "touched" for data coverage statistic.

content.text: One of the benefits of universal
is that your test is focused on the data and not implementation details.
But what if you decided to use a custom component to enter the data?
To hide implementation details from your test you should define a custom input handler for your UI component.
Let's consider a form component that you can start interacting with only after you clicked it. And after the value
is entered, the input box disappears again.

content.snippet: current value
content.title: Custom input

content.text: Our test should still be written in terms of data entering and validation.

content.title: set value to custom component

content.text: In order to achieve this we need to register a custom handler.

content.snippet:
import formHandlers.CustomInput

url = "http://localhost:8180"

pageElementGetSetValueHandlers = [CustomInput]

Out of the box report provides high level information like number of failed tests and HTTP Operations coverage.

content.text: Robust tests should not depend on implementation details.
UI test should not depend on any of them.
Move elements placement and available actions outside of UI test.
Multiple tests can then reuse that information.
And more importantly you will have only one place to change if UI changes.
To make it easier to refer
from different tests combine them in one file
Use static import to have seamless access to all of them

content.snippet:
package scenarios.ui

import static com.twosigma.webtau.WebTauGroovyDsl.*
import static pages.Pages.*

scenario("search by specific query") {
    search.submit("search this")
    search.numberOfResults.should == 2
}

content.text: Webtau supports validation of responses against an
configuration option.  This should be the URL to the specification against

content.snippet:
url = "http://localhost:8080"
openApiSpecUrl = 'api-spec.json'
content.title: Configuration

content.text: OpenAPI specification support is still in its early stage.  It is fully functional but there are a few limitations to be
webtau currently only supports OpenAPI specification v2
specification matching is currently done based on the path and method
any HTTP requests which do not match any operation in the specification will not fail tests but will produce a warning
The validation errors are reported in the same manner as assertion errors.  They are available in the output from the
They are also available in the HTML report:
To ignore additional properties in responses set
As any other config value it can be done via command line, config file or system properties.

content.snippet: import com.twosigma.webtau.openapi.OpenApi
content.title: Additional import
Disable request and response validation
Disable request validation
Disable response validation

content.text: so users can use them to achieve various goals.
You also need to make sure that documented scenarios work as advertised.
To automate the process, capture executed scenarios and use them inside your documentation.

content.text: directory will be created containing a number of test artifacts.
By default, the directory will be created in the current working directory.

url = "http://localhost:8180"

content.title: webtau.cfg

content.text: A number of artifacts will be created depending on the exact call being captured.
Request bodies are captured in either
Similarly, response bodies are captured in either
Just like payloads, request and response headers are captured in
respectively. These files contain a header per line with the name and values colon separated.  The values
are redacted for any potentially sensitive headers.
Any assertions you perform on the response body in your scenarios are captured in a
contains an array with the list of paths within the body whose values were asserted.
The actual request URL is captured in two forms into two different files:
- contains only the part specified in the http call in the scenario

content.snippet: /params?a=1&b=text
content.title: request.url.txt

content.text: If you have user facing scenario tests, capture them and refer to them inside your documentation.
Set your documentation build pipeline like below.

content.text: Combine REST requests and responses with Open API generated specs for complete documentation.
You can use maven to add webtau as a dependency to you project (for autocompletion or to use with JUnit like runners).

content.snippet:
<dependency>
    <groupId>com.twosigma.webtau</groupId>
    <artifactId>webtau-groovy</artifactId>
    <version>1.16-SNAPSHOT</version>
</dependency>

<dependency>
    <groupId>com.twosigma.webtau</groupId>
    <artifactId>webtau</artifactId>
    <version>1.16-SNAPSHOT</version>
</dependency>

content.text: Use maven plugin to run pure groovy tests as part of your build.

content.snippet:
<plugin>
    <groupId>com.twosigma.webtau</groupId>
    <artifactId>webtau-maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>1.16-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <phase>test</phase>
            <goals>
                <goal>run</goal>
            </goals>
        </execution>
    </executions>
    <configuration>
        <workingDir>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</workingDir>
        <env>integration</env>
        <url>http://optional-base-url</url>
        <tests>
            <directory>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</directory>
            <includes>
                <include>scenarios/simple*.groovy</include>
            </includes>
        </tests>
    </configuration>
</plugin>

One of the benefits of separating one CRUD
into multiple is to be able to run one test at a time.
In order to do it we will use

content.title: CRUD separated
Customer lazy resource

content.text: Note: to run one scenario at a time use
As you can see in the report below, each
operation has its own entry. If you follow this pattern, then you
The default mode for running tests is serially; in other words, scenario files are executed one after the other.
Webtau supports executing tests in parallel.  In this mode,
For large test suites, it is therefore advisable to create many small focused scenario files instead of few large files.
To enable parallel execution, specify the
configuration property either through the configuration file
or as a CLI parameter.  This property dictates the maximum number of threads on which to run tests.  Alternatively,
and webtau will use as many threads as there are scenario files.
Note: scenario file execution order is not guaranteed.
Webtau via CLI or Maven plugin supports a number of methods for specifying and discovering scenarios.
The simplest way is to list the scenario files explicitly:

content.snippet:
<plugin>
    <groupId>com.twosigma.webtau</groupId>
    <artifactId>webtau-maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>1.16-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <phase>test</phase>
            <goals>
                <goal>run</goal>
            </goals>
        </execution>
    </executions>
    <configuration>
        <workingDir>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</workingDir>
        <env>integration</env>
        <url>http://optional-base-url</url>
        <tests>
            <directory>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</directory>
            <includes>
                <include>scenarios/simpleGet.groovy</include>
                <include>scenarios/simplePost.groovy</include>
            </includes>
        </tests>
    </configuration>
</plugin>

content.text: Wildcard matching is also supported.  In the CLI version this is normal shell [glob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glob_(programming)
and in Maven it's a standard Maven file inclusion block:

content.snippet:
<plugin>
    <groupId>com.twosigma.webtau</groupId>
    <artifactId>webtau-maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>1.16-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <phase>test</phase>
            <goals>
                <goal>run</goal>
            </goals>
        </execution>
    </executions>
    <configuration>
        <workingDir>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</workingDir>
        <env>integration</env>
        <url>http://optional-base-url</url>
        <tests>
            <directory>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</directory>
            <includes>
                <include>scenarios/simple*.groovy</include>
            </includes>
        </tests>
    </configuration>
</plugin>

content.text: It is also possible to include a set of base directories and webtau will then find all

content.snippet:
<plugin>
    <groupId>com.twosigma.webtau</groupId>
    <artifactId>webtau-maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>1.16-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <phase>test</phase>
            <goals>
                <goal>run</goal>
            </goals>
        </execution>
    </executions>
    <configuration>
        <workingDir>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</workingDir>
        <env>integration</env>
        <url>http://optional-base-url</url>
        <tests>
            <directory>${project.basedir}/src/main/groovy</directory>
        </tests>
    </configuration>
</plugin>

content.text: In this mode, the HTML report that webtau generates will show paths to the files relative to the
Robust tests don't specify the full URL of an application under test.
Instead you only pass a relative URL to functions like
Define base URL portion either inside a

content.text: or pass as a command line argument
Webtau supports validation of objects against
.  It is possible to validate either
the entire body or just a specific field with the
matcher as shown in the two examples below:

content.title: Validate entire body against JSON schema
Validate specific field against JSON schema

content.text: Both examples above validate against the following schema:

content.title: Correct schema for the example above

content.text: Using the first example above, an invalid schema will generate an error similar to:

content.snippet:
invalid schema (examples/scenarios/rest/jsonSchema/validateSchema.groovy)
> executing HTTP GET http://localhost:8080/weather
  X failed expecting body to comply with schema invalid-schema.json : 
      body expected to comply with schema invalid-schema.json
      [#: required key [anotherField] not found, #/temperature: expected type: Boolean, found: Integer]
{
  "temperature": 88
}

content.text: The schema used in validation to generate this error is as follows:

content.title: Incorrect schema for the example above

content.text: The path to the schema file specified in
can be relative or absolute.  If it's relative, it'll be
specified in configuration and if not specified then relative to working directory.

content.snippet:
url = "http://localhost:8180"
jsonSchemasDir = 'schemas'
content.title: Configuration

content.text: Lets consider a simple web page that displays a value from a local storage.

content.title: Sample web page

content.snippet:
package scenarios.ui

import static com.twosigma.webtau.WebTauGroovyDsl.*

scenario("local storage api") {
    browser.open('/local-storage')
    browser.localStorage.setItem('favoriteColor', 'clean')

    def color = $('#favorite-color')

    browser.reopen('/local-storage')
    color.should == 'clean'

    browser.localStorage.clear()
    browser.reopen('/local-storage')
    color.should == ''
}
content.title: Setting storage after opening page
Local Storage methods

content.text: When payload content is present then values are based on the content type you are sending.
When no payload is present, it defaults to
If each http request requires the same header you can specify that header using
Common example is specifying authentication header.

content.snippet:
import scenarios.rest.headers.auth.Auth

url = "http://localhost:8080"

httpHeaderProvider = Auth.&authHeader
content.title: webtau.cfg
scenarios/rest/headers/auth/Auth.groovy

content.text: This removes implementation details from your tests and makes them less brittle.

content.snippet:
def varArgHeader = http.header(
        'My-Header1', 'Value1',
        'My-Header2', 'Value2')

def mapBasedHeader = http.header([
        'My-Header1': 'Value1',
        'My-Header2': 'Value2'])

assert varArgHeader == mapBasedHeader

content.title: Combined type and payload
content.entry: explicit binary mime types combined with request body

content.text: If you need a standard type consider using

content.title: Binary content shortuct
content.entry: post implicit binary mime types combined with request body

content.title: Text content shortcut
content.entry: implicit text mime types combined with request body

content.text: To validate values from response header use

content.snippet:
http.post("/end-point") {
    header.location.should == 'http://www.example.org/url/23'
    header['Location'].should == 'http://www.example.org/url/23'

    header.contentLocation.should == '/url/23'
    header['Content-Location'].should == '/url/23'

    header.contentLength.shouldBe > 300
    header['Content-Length'].shouldBe > 300
}

content.text: All the other header values you need to use
To document how to use a User Interface we often take screenshots and annotate them.
At the same time we need to make sure that documented scenario works as advertised.
With UI testing we can validate scenarios and at the same time capture screenshots with automatically placed annotations.

content.snippet:
search.submit("search this")

browser.doc.withAnnotations(
        browser.doc.badge(search.box),
        browser.doc.badge(search.results)).capture('search')
content.title: screenshot capture with badge annotations

content.text: command is two files: actual screenshot and

content.title: search.json

content.text: plugin that supports annotations format generated by

content.snippet: :include-image: doc-artifacts/search.png {fit: true, annotationsPath: "doc-artifacts/search.json"}

search.submit("search this")

browser.doc.withAnnotations(
        browser.doc.badge(search.box),
        browser.doc.badge(search.results)).capture('search')
content.title: badges

content.snippet:
browser.doc.withAnnotations(
        browser.doc.highlight(search.box),
        browser.doc.cover(search.results, "covering text")).capture('search-highlight-cover')
content.title: cover and highlight

shortcut if you need to skip tests for certain environment.

content.snippet: import static com.twosigma.webtau.WebTauGroovyDsl.*
content.title: Single import to use

content.text: Identifiers inside validation closure are automatically mapped to a response body.
List responses are handled by using index chain
, but if you need to deal with array response you need to access values using
Matchers in webtau are triggered with
alias keywords are available to make certain matcher combinations easier to read.
Webtau defines its own set of equality rules to simplify testing.

content.snippet:
http.get("/end-point") {
    id.should != 0
    amount.should == 30

    list.should == [1, 2, 3]

    object.k1.should == ~/v\d/ // regular expression matching

    object.should == [k1: 'v1', k3: 'v3'] // matching only specified fields and can be nested multiple times

    complexList.should == ["k1"   | "k2"] { // matching only specified fields, but number of entries must be exact
                           ________________
                            "v1"  | 30
                            "v11" | 40 }
}

http.doc.capture("end-point-object-equality-matchers")

http.get("/end-point-numbers") {
    id.shouldBe > 0
    price.shouldBe >= 100
    amount.shouldBe < 150
    list[1].shouldBe <= 2

    id.shouldNotBe <= 0
    price.shouldNotBe < 100
    amount.shouldNotBe >= 150
    list[1].shouldNotBe > 2
}

http.doc.capture("end-point-numbers-matchers")
content.entry: compare numbers with greater less matchers

content.text: when you cannot rely on order of values in a response.
You can use matchers in place of expected values to build a more complex expectation.

content.snippet:
http.get("/end-point-mixed") {
    list.should contain(lessThanOrEqual(2)) // lessThanOrEqual will be matched against each value

    object.should == [k1: 'v1', k3: ~/v\d/] // regular expression match against k3

    complexList[0].should == [k1: 'v1', k2: lessThan(120)] // lessThen match against k2

    complexList[1].should == [
        k1: notEqual('v1'), // any value but v1
        k2: greaterThanOrEqual(120)]

    complexList.should == ["k1"   | "k2"] {
                          ___________________________
                           ~/v\d/ | lessThan(120)
                            "v11" | greaterThan(150) } // using matchers as cell values
}

http.doc.capture("end-point-mixing-matchers")

content.text: Many actions in a modern web page are asynchronous. User presses a button and a moment later a result appears.
In modern web pages there is no full page reload and only a portion of a page will be changed.
If a test will try to assert a value after a user action, chances are assertion will fail since it will take time
for a result to appear on a page.
Question: How do users know that their action is done and they can move on?
One way to deal with asynchronous pages is to wait for a feedback to appear or disappear.

content.snippet:
calculation.start()

calculation.feedback.waitTo beVisible()
calculation.results.should == [100, 230]
content.title: beVisible matcher

content.text: Disabled input box and buttons can be used as a user feedback as well.

content.snippet:
calculation.open()

calculation.input.waitTo beEnabled()
calculation.input.setValue(100)
content.title: beEnabled matcher

content.text: If presence/absence of an element is not important, you can directly to wait for a matcher to match.

content.snippet:
calculation.start()
calculation.results.waitTo == [100, 230]
content.title: waitTo any matcher

content.text: Note: any matcher that you can use with
Another cue to use could be a url change after an action.

content.snippet:
browser.open('/resource-creation')

$('#new').click()
browser.url.ref.waitTo == 'created-id'

content.text: Note: url exposes other parts that you can
represent an element that is present or
on a web page. It is safe to declare an element
before you open a browser or navigate to the page you need to test.
Consider a simple search page. Enter value, hit enter, see results.

content.snippet:
package scenarios.ui

import static com.twosigma.webtau.WebTauGroovyDsl.*

scenario('search by specific query') {
    browser.open('/search')

    $('#search-box').setValue('search this')
    $('#search-box').sendKeys("\n")

    $('#results .result').count.shouldBe > 1
}

content.text: represents the number of elements matching the css selector.
